intro: Dryandra viscida, commonly known as the sticky dryandra, is a species of flowering plant native to Western Australia. It belongs to the family Proteaceae and is characterized by its distinctive, often hairy leaves and showy, pinkish-white flowers. The plant is known for its sticky secretions, which give it its common name and help in deterring herbivores. It typically grows in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in open woodlands or heathlands. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is of interest to botanists and conservationists.
